name: 🟢 Tab
htmlBanner:
Tab

Tabs are a navigational component used to organize and navigate between different sections of content.

Accessibility.html:
Overview

Tabs are a set of layered sections of content, known as tab panels, that display one panel of content at a time. Each tab panel has an associated tab element, that when activated, displays the panel. The list of tab elements is arranged along one edge of the currently displayed panel, most commonly the top edge. Refer to W3C for more guidance on Tabs.

Interaction guidance

Pointer gestures

Buttons have the pointer type cursor on hover.

Keyboard interactions

For the tab list:
Tab:
When focus moves into the tab list, places focus on the active tab element.
When the tab list contains the focus, moves focus to the next element in the page tab sequence outside the tab-list, which is the tab-panel unless the first element containing meaningful content inside the tab-panel is focusable.

Screen reader

The element that serves as the container for the set of tabs has role tab-list. Each element that serves as a tab has role tab and is contained within the element with role tab-list. Each element that contains the content panel for a tab has role tab-panel. If the tab list has a visible label, the element with role tab-list has aria-labelledby set to a value that refers to the labelling element. Otherwise, the tab-list element has a label provided by aria-label. Each element with role tab has the property aria-controls referring to its associated tab-panel element. The active tab element has the state aria-selected set to true and all other tab elements have it set to false. Each element with role tab-panel has the property aria-labelledby referring to its associated tab element. If a tab element has a popup menu, it has the property aria-haspopup set to either menu or true. If the tab-list element is vertically oriented, it has the property aria-orientation

Guideline.html:
Anatomy

Use Cases

Tabs are used to house multiple types of content within the same context, either taking over the whole page/interface or a small section of a page. The active tab indicates which piece of content is being shown.

Tabs can be used in a variety of scenarios, including:
Navigation: Use tabs to allow users to navigate between different sections of content, such as different pages or categories.
Multi-step processes: Use tabs to break down a multi-step process into smaller, more manageable sections, allowing users to focus on one step at a time.

When to use

When there are multiple categories or sections of content to display.
When users need to switch between different views or filters.
When there are multiple steps in a process that users need to complete.

When Not to Use

While tabs can be a useful way to organize content, there are some scenarios where they might not be appropriate. Here are some examples:
When there are only one or two sections of content to display.
When users need to view multiple sections of content simultaneously.
Common controls; you may want to use a segmented button for interface controls that don’t showcase different type

Types

There are two types of Tabs, a primary Pill style, and a secondary Line style.

Pill Tabs

Primary tab component. Placed at the top of the content pane under a top app bar. They display the main content destinations.

Line Tabs

Secondary tab type, used within a content area to further separate related content and establish hierarchy.

Behavior

States

Tabs can be Active or Inactive, and contain states for each level of activity.

Overflow arrows

By default, overflow arrows are disabled. However, if a set of tabs cannot fit on screen, they will appear to allow the user to view all tabs within a given context.

Click on the arrow to show the next full tab in that direction.

If a tab is cutoff, when clicking on that tab, the menu moves so that the new activated tab is seen.

Tabs can be Active or Inactive, and contain states for each level of activity.

Scrollable content

When a screen scrolls up and down through content, tabs can either be fixed to the top of the screen, or scroll off the screen. If they scroll off the screen, they will return when the user scrolls upward.

If the tab bar is fixed, clicking on a new tab will take the user to the top of the activated page.

Badges

If a tab has a badge, that badge will disappear once the user clicks on that tab.

Dos and Dont’s

Truncation

Use clear, simple label names

Do not truncate labels or drop labels to a second line. If your label is too long, work with a content designer to identify a better label.

Icons

Keep icon usage consistent across all tabs.

Do not use icons on only a few tabs.

Content

Casing

Use simple and precise tab labels for clarity. Aim for one to two words for ease of scanning. Ensure text labels effectively convey the displayed view and its contents.

Useable Examples
